data.title: Books Received
data.text:
Mark I. West

Canadian Children's Books: A Critical Guide to Authors and Illustrators. 2nd ed. By Raymond E. Jones and Jon C. Stott. Oxford, New York, and Toronto: Oxford UP, 2000.

This edition is substantially longer than the original edition, which Harcourt, Brace, and Jovanovich published in 1988. The new Oxford edition consists of 133 biocritical essays on authors and illustrators who have made significant contributions to Canadian children's literature. Appendices contain lists of Canadian book award winners and sources for additional study.

Exploring C.S. Lewis' The Chronicles of Narnia. By Kirk H. Beetz. Osprey, FL: Beacham, 2001.

The second volume in a series titled Beacham's Sourcebooks, this 600-page book provides extensive background information about CS. Lewis and his writings for children. The opening chapters focus on the life and theology of C.S. Lewis. There are also chapters on each of the seven books that comprise The Chronicles of Narnia.

Many People, One Land: A Guide to New Multicultural Literature for Children and Young Adults. By Alethea K. Helbig and Agnes Regan Perkins. Westport, CT: Greenwood, 2001.

This book is a follow-up volume to Helbig and Perkins' This Land is Our Land, which came out in 1994. Like its predecessor, Many Peoples, One Land is an annotated listing of children's books that focus on African Americans, Asian Americans, Hispanic Americans, or Native-Americans. In this new volume, Helbig and Perkins cover 541 books published from 1994 through 1999.

The Newbery and Caldecott Medal Books, 1986-2000: A Comprehensive Guide to the Winners. Ed. Kathleen Horning, Maria Salvadore, and Roger Sutton. Chicago: American Library Association, 2001.

The Horn Book and the Association for Library Service to Children collaborated on the production of this volume. Organized chronologically, each year's entry features reviews from Horn Book Magazine and Booklist, acceptance speeches, and biographical essays about the winners.

Norma Fox Mazer: A Writer's World. By Arthea J.S. Reed. Lanham, MD: Scarecrow, 2000.

The third volume in Scarecrow Studies in Young Adult Literature series, this book is as much a biography of Mazer as it is a critical study of Mazer's various young adult novels, such as After the Rain, Taking Terri Mueller, and When She Was Good. Reed pays particular attention to the relationship between Norma Fox Mazer and her husband, Harry Mazer, who also writes for young adults.

Reading Comprehension: Strategies for Independent Learners. By Camille Blachowicz and Donna Ogle. New York: Guilford, 2001.

Intended for an audience of reading teachers, this book provides suggestions on how teachers can help improve students' reading comprehension. The chapter titled "Strategies for Reading Fiction" is of particular interest to children's literature specialists.

Talking Books: Children's Authors Talk about the Craft, Creativity and Process of Writing. By James Carter. London and New York: Routledge, 1999.

Talking Books is a collection of interviews with thirteen British children's authors, including Helen Cresswell, Gillian Cross, and Philip Pullman.

Tutoring Programs for Struggling Readers. Ed. Lesley Mandel Morrow and Deborah Gee Woo. New York: Guilford, 2001.

The contributors to this volume describe exemplary tutoring programs that were created in response to the America Read Challenge Act of 1997. Many of the contributors discuss the importance of incorporating children's literature into tutoring programs. [End Page 52]
